relation: IMT (Failing JUnit test does not reproduce locally)
pageTitle: WTP Smoke Test Results R325 10272011 - Eclipsepedia
title: This Week's Results
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {21044=This page was last modified 11:06, 1 November 2011 by Carl Anderson. Based on work by Nitin Dahyabhai, Neil Hauge and Keith Chong and others., 25301=Copyright © 2014 The Eclipse Foundation. All Rights Reserved.}
textBeforeTable: Keep in mind the threshold for promoting a build gets higher as we near a milestone or near a release. Remember the significant column for promoting a build is the left-most project column. If some component within a project has not (or can not) be tested, the Project Lead should either make sure someone does the test, or make a judgment call on if the build (from their project's point of view) can be promoted or not. If the smoke test could not be performed, a note should be made in the comments section that it wasn't performed, why, and why that should prevent promotion. If a build can be promoted and no issues were found, simple use the green check mark and include the initials or names of who performed the test. If a smoke test does not pass but the build can still be promoted, use a green check mark (ok) icon () but then document in the comments bug numbers, how the smoke test fails, workarounds, or cautions about the build. Use a red X (fail) icon () to signify that the build should not be promoted, that a respin is required. In that case, please provide bug number and be sure those that need to fix something are aware of it, and can arrange for a respin. Once the issue has been fixed, and confirmed, change the red
